sen.j: 大報恩寺（だいほうおんじ）は京都市上京区にある真言宗智山派の寺院で山号は瑞応山。
sen.e: Daiho-Onji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan Branch of the Shingon Sect located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Daiho-Onji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan Branch of the Shingon Sect located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Daihoon-ji Temple is a Buddhist temple belonging to the Chizan school of the Shingon Sect located in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: Daihoon-ji Temple, Chizan school of the Shingon Sectとしました。

sen.j: 通称千本釈迦堂。
sen.e: It is commonly known as Senbon-Dhaka-do.
It is commonly known as Senbon-Dhaka-do.
It is commonly known as Senbon-Shaka-do.

sen.j: おかめの物語や、12月の風物詩である大根焚きで知られる。
sen.e: The temple is known for Okame-no-monogatari (The Story of Okame) and Daikon-daki (daikon radish cooking festival).
The temple is known for Okame-no-monogatari (The Story of Okame) and Daikon-daki (daikon radish cooking festival).
The temple is known for Okame no monogatari (The Story of Okame) and Daikon-daki (daikon radish cooking festival) which is the signature December event.
sen.cmt: Okame no monogatariとしました。「12月の風物詩」を訳出

sen.j: 鎌倉時代初期の安貞元年（1227年）義空によって創建された。
sen.e: Daiho-Onji Temple was founded by Giku in 1227, during the Kamakura period.
Daiho-Onji Temple was founded by Giku in 1227, during the Kamakura period.
Daihoon-ji Temple was founded by Giku in 1227, during the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 義空は藤原秀衡の孫で叡山で修行の後ここを建立した。
sen.e: Giku was the grandson of FUJIWARA no Hidehira and founded the temple after studying at Mt. Hiei.
Giku was the grandson of FUJIWARA no Hidehira and founded the temple after studying at Mt. Hiei.
Giku was the grandson of FUJIWARA no Hidehira and founded the temple after studying at Mt. Hiei.

sen.j: 本堂は摂津の材木商の寄進をうけ完成した。
sen.e: The main hall was completed using donations contributed by a by Settsu lumber dealer.
The main hall was completed using donations contributed by a by Settsu lumber dealer.
The main hall was completed using donations contributed by a by Settsu lumber dealer.

sen.j: 本堂の建立に関して大工の妻の「おかめ」に関する伝説が伝えられている（後述）。
sen.e: A legend is told regarding 'Okame', the wife of a carpenter who worked on the construction of the main hall (described below)
A legend is told regarding 'Okame', the wife of a carpenter who worked on the construction of the main hall (described below)
A legend is told regarding 'Okame,' the wife of a carpenter who worked on the construction of the main hall (described below).
sen.cmt: カンマの位置を移動、文末のピリオドを追加。

sen.j: 倶舎（くしゃ）・天台・真言の三宗兼学を朝廷より許された。
sen.e: The Imperial Court permitted the temple to be used by the Kusha, Tendai and Shingon sects.
The Imperial Court permitted the temple to be used by the Kusha, Tendai and Shingon sects.
The Imperial Court permitted the temple to be used by the Kusha, Tendai and Shingon sects.

sen.j: この本堂は応仁文明の乱にも焼けることはなく創建当時のもので洛中最古の建造物で国宝となっている。
sen.e: The original main hall dating from the time of the temple's founding was not burnt during the Onin War and has been designated a National Treasure as the oldest building in central Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 「応仁文明の乱」は「応仁の乱」のことで、「Onin War」を定訳として使いました。
sen.e: The original main hall dating from the time of the temple's founding was not burnt during the Onin War and has been designated a National Treasure as the oldest building in central Kyoto.
The original main hall dating from the time of the temple's founding was not burnt during the Onin War and has been designated a National Treasure as the oldest building in central Kyoto.

sen.j: 大報恩寺には近隣の北野天神（北野天満宮）門前にあった「北野経王堂」の遺物も保管されている。
sen.e: The remains of "Kitano Kyoo-do Hall" that once stood in front of the gate of Kitano Tenjin Shrine (Kitano Tenman-gu), neighboring Daiho-Onji Temple, have also been preserved.
The remains of "Kitano Kyoo-do Hall" that once stood in front of the gate of Kitano Tenjin Shrine (Kitano Tenman-gu), neighboring Daiho-Onji Temple, have also been preserved.
The remains of 'Kitano Kyoo-do Hall' that once stood in front of the gate of Kitano Tenjin Shrine (Kitano Tenman-gu Shrine), neighboring Daihoon-ji Temple, have also been preserved.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、Kitano Tenman-gu Shrine, Daihoon-ji Templeとしました。

sen.j: 北野経王堂は、足利義満が明徳の乱（山名氏清の乱）の戦没者を悼んで応永8年（1401年）に建立したものであったが、明治初年の神仏分離によって破却された。
sen.e: Kitano Kyoo-do Hall was constructed by Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA in 1401 in memory of those who died in the Meitoku Rebellion (Ujikiya YAMANA-no-ran) but was demolished as part of the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism that took place during the Meiji era.

Kitano Kyoo-do Hall was constructed by Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA in 1401 in memory of those who died in the Meitoku Rebellion (Ujikiya YAMANA-no-ran) but was demolished as part of the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism that took place during the Meiji era.

Kitano Kyoo-do Hall was constructed by Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA in 1401 in memory of those who died in the Meitoku War (the War of Ujikiyo YAMANA) but was demolished as part of the separation of Buddhism and Shintoism that took place in the early part of the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: Ujikiyoのスペルミスを修正、"the Meitoku War (the War of Ujikiyo YAMANA)"としました。明治初年→in the early part of the Meiji periodとしました。

tit.e: Okame no Monogatari (The Story of Okame)

sen.j: 本堂を造営する際、大工の棟梁であった高次が代りのない柱の寸法を切り誤ってしまい困っていた。
sen.e: During the construction of the main hall, master carpenter Takatsugi cut an irreplaceable pillar to the wrong size.
During the construction of the main hall, master carpenter Takatsugi cut an irreplaceable pillar to the wrong size.
During the construction of the main hall, master carpenter Takatsugi cut an irreplaceable pillar to the wrong size.

sen.j: それを見た妻のおかめが枡組を用いたらどうかとひと言アドバイスし結果無事に竣工させることができた。
sen.e: On seeing this, his wife Okame advised him that he could correct the problem using a bracket complex, and the building was completed on time.
On seeing this, his wife Okame advised him that he could correct the problem using a bracket complex, and the building was completed on time.
On seeing this, his wife Okame advised him that he could correct the problem using a bracket complex, and the building was completed on time.

sen.j: おかめは女の提案で大任を果たしたことが知れてはと上棟式を待たずに自害してしまった。
sen.e: Okame then committed suicide before the ridgepole-raising ceremony to prevent it from becoming known that it was the suggestion of a woman that allowed this important task to be accomplished.
Okame then committed suicide before the ridgepole-raising ceremony to prevent it from becoming known that it was the suggestion of a woman that allowed this important task to be accomplished.
Okame then committed suicide before the ridgepole-raising ceremony to prevent it from becoming known that it was the suggestion of a woman that allowed this important task to be accomplished.

sen.j: 高次は妻の冥福を祈り宝篋印塔（おかめ塚）を建て、おかめの名にちなんだ福面を付けた扇御幣を飾ったとされる。
sen.e: The Hogyoin-to (Okame-zuka) was built to pray for the soul of Takatsugi's wife and it is believed that Okame gohei (wooden stands with paper streamers and an Okame face) were derived from her legend.
The Hogyoin-to (Okame-zuka) was built to pray for the soul of Takatsugi's wife and it is believed that Okame gohei (wooden stands with paper streamers and an Okame face) were derived from her legend.
The Hogyoin-to (Okame-zuka) was built to pray for the soul of Takatsugi's wife and it is believed that Okame gohei (wooden stands with paper streamers and an Okame face) were derived from her legend.

sen.j: その後、大工の信仰を得るようになり今日でも上棟式にはお多福の面を着けた御幣が飾られている。
sen.e: Okame later became worshipped by carpenters and even today gohei with Otafuku (Okame) masks are used as decoration at ridgepole-raising ceremonies.
Okame later became worshipped by carpenters and even today gohei with Otafuku (Okame) masks are used as decoration at ridgepole-raising ceremonies.
Okame later became worshipped by carpenters and even today gohei with Otafuku (Okame) masks are used as decoration at ridgepole-raising ceremonies.

sen.j: 度重なる戦乱にも残った本堂とも結びつき厄除、招福のおかめ信仰につながっている。
sen.e: These are related to the main hall as it has survived numerous conflicts and is connected to the belief that Okame wards off evil and invites good luck.
These are related to the main hall as it has survived numerous conflicts and is connected to the belief that Okame wards off evil and invites good luck.
These are related to the main hall as it has survived numerous conflicts and is connected to the belief that Okame wards off evil and invites good luck.

sen.j: 節分会 - おかめ節分ともいわれ2月の節分におかめ塚で豆まきがおかめ音頭などが行われる。
sen.e: Setsubun-e: This February festival is also known as 'Okame Setsubun' in which a bean-throwing ceremony and Okame Ondo (folk music) takes place at Okame-zuka.
Setsubun-e: This February festival is also known as 'Okame Setsubun' in which a bean-throwing ceremony and Okame Ondo (folk music) takes place at Okame-zuka.
Setsubun-e: This February festival is also known as 'Okame Setsubun' in which a bean-throwing ceremony and Okame Ondo (folk music) takes place at Okame-zuka.

sen.j: 千本の釈迦念仏 - 遺教経会ともいわれる。
sen.e: Senbon Shaka Nenbutsu: Also known as 'Yuikyogyo-e'.
Senbon Shaka Nenbutsu: Also known as 'Yuikyogyo-e'.
Senbon Shaka Nenbutsu: Also known as 'Yuikyogyo-e'.

sen.j: 二世の如輪により文永年間に始められた。
sen.e: Started during the Bunei era (1264-1275) by the second head priest Nyorin.
Started during the Bunei era (1264-1275) by the second head priest Nyorin.
Started during the Bunei era (1264-1275) by the second head priest Nyorin.

sen.j: 吉田兼好の徒然草にも記録がある。
sen.e: Also recorded in Kenko YOSHIDA's 'Tsurezuregusa' (Essays in Idleness).
Also recorded in Kenko YOSHIDA's 'Tsurezuregusa' (Essays in Idleness).
Also recorded in Kenko YOSHIDA's Tsurezuregusa (Essays in Idleness).
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせ、Tsurezuregusaのクォーテーションをとりました。

sen.j: 大根焚き - 12月7日･12月8日に行なわれる成道会法要。
sen.e: Daikon-daki: A Buddhist Bodhi Day service held on the December 7th and 8th.
Daikon-daki: A Buddhist Bodhi Day service held on the December 7th and 8th.
Daikon-daki: A Buddhist Bodhi Day service held on the December 7 and 8.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代に、当寺の僧・慈禅が、法要の際に大根の切り口に梵字を書いて息災祈願を行なったのが起源とされ、今日では、この大根を食べると中風など諸病除けになるとされている。
sen.e: Originated during the Kamakura period when Jizen, a monk at Daiho-Onji Temple, would write Sanskrit characters on the cut end of daikon radishes and pray for good health, and today it is believed that eating these daikon radishes can cure ailments such as paralysis.

Originated during the Kamakura period when Jizen, a monk at Daiho-Onji Temple, would write Sanskrit characters on the cut end of daikon radishes and pray for good health, and today it is believed that eating these daikon radishes can cure ailments such as paralysis.

Originated during the Kamakura period when Jizen, a monk at Daihoon-ji Temple, would write Sanskrit characters on the cut end of daikon radishes and pray for good health, and today it is believed that eating these daikon radishes can cure ailments such as paralysis.

sen.j: 本堂（附 厨子、旧棟木、棟札）
sen.e: Main hall (including a miniature shrine, an old ridge beam and a ridgepole sign)
Main hall (including a miniature shrine, an old ridge beam and a ridgepole sign)
Main hall (including a miniature shrine, an old ridge beam and a ridgepole sign)

sen.j: 木造釈迦如来坐像（附 天蓋）－当寺の本尊。
sen.e: Wooden statue of Shakya Nyorai (including canopy): The temple's principal image.
Wooden statue of Shakya Nyorai (including canopy): The temple's principal image.
Wooden statue of Shakya Nyorai (including canopy): The temple's principal image.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の仏師快慶の弟子である行快の作。
sen.e: Created by Gyokai, the disciple of Kamakura period Buddhist sculptor Kaikei.
Created by Gyokai, the disciple of Kamakura period Buddhist sculptor Kaikei.
Created by Gyokai, the disciple of Kamakura period Buddhist sculptor Kaikei.

sen.j: （秘仏）
sen.e: It is ordinarily kept hidden from view.
It is ordinarily kept hidden from view.
It is ordinarily kept hidden from view.

sen.j: 木造十大弟子立像 10躯（附 像内納入経）－納入品や銘記から建保6年（1218年）快慶の作と判明する。
sen.e: 10 wooden standing statues of the 10 great disciples (including sutras within the statues): The items within the statues and inscriptions have confirmed that they were created by Kaikei.
10 wooden standing statues of the 10 great disciples (including sutras within the statues): The items within the statues and inscriptions have confirmed that they were created by Kaikei.

Wooden standing statues of the 10 great disciples, 10 statues (including sutras within the statues): The items within the statues and inscriptions have confirmed that they were created by Kaikei in 1218.
sen.cmt: 文頭の10をとり、"10 statues"の表記を新たに加えました。年号追加

sen.j: 木造六観音像 6躯（附 像内納入経）－定慶作。
sen.e: 6 wooden statues of Kannon (including sutras within the statues): Created by Jokei.
6 wooden statues of Kannon (including sutras within the statues): Created by Jokei.
Wooden statues of the six Kannon, six statues (including sutras within the statues): Created by Jokei.
sen.cmt: Wooden statues of the six Kannonとし、"six statues"を加えました。

sen.j: 聖観音、十一面観音、千手観音、如意輪観音、馬頭観音、准胝観音の6体。
sen.e: These six statues depict Sho Kannon, Eleven-faced Kannon, Thousand-armed Kannon, Nyoirin Kannon, Horse-headed Kannon and Juntei Kannon.
These six statues depict Sho Kannon, Eleven-faced Kannon, Thousand-armed Kannon, Nyoirin Kannon, Horse-headed Kannon and Juntei Kannon.
These six statues depict Sho Kannon, Eleven-faced Kannon, Thousand-armed Kannon, Nyoirin Kannon, Horse-headed Kannon and Juntei Kannon.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には「定慶」という名の仏師が他にもいるが、本群像の作者は「肥後別当定慶」である。
sen.e: There were other Buddhist sculptors by the name of 'Jokei' during the Kamakura period, but these statues were created by 'Higo Betto Jokei'.
There were other Buddhist sculptors by the name of 'Jokei' during the Kamakura period, but these statues were created by 'Higo Betto Jokei'.
There were other Buddhist sculptors by the name of 'Jokei' during the Kamakura period, but these statues were created by 'Higo Betto Jokei'.

sen.j: 作風には宋風が顕著で、写実的な表情と絵画的で複雑な衣文が特色である。
sen.e: The statues have a striking Chinese Song Dynasty style, and feature realistic facial expressions and picturesque elaborate clothing.
The statues have a striking Chinese Song Dynasty style, and feature realistic facial expressions and picturesque elaborate clothing.
The statues have a striking Chinese Song Dynasty style, and feature realistic facial expressions and picturesque elaborate clothing.

sen.j: 等身大の六観音像が揃って残るのは珍しい。
sen.e: It is amazing that these six life-sized Kannon statues have remained together.
It is amazing that these six life-sized Kannon statues have remained together.
It is amazing that these six life-sized Kannon statues have remained together.

sen.j: 北野経王堂旧所在。
sen.e: Located in the Kitano Kyoo-do Hall.
Located in the Kitano Kyoo-do Hall.
Located in the Kitano Kyoo-do Hall.

sen.j: 銅造誕生釈迦仏立像
sen.e: Bronze standing statue of Shakya Nyorai's birth
Bronze standing statue of Shakya Nyorai's birth
Bronze standing statue of Shakya Nyorai's birth

sen.j: 木造千手観音立像
sen.e: Wooden statue of the Thousand-armed Kannon
Wooden statue of the Thousand-armed Kannon
Wooden statue of the Thousand-armed Kannon

sen.j: 木造傳大士（ふたいし）及二童子像 3躯－北野経王堂の遺物である。
sen.e: 3 wooden statues of Futaishi and two children: Remenant of Kitano Kyoo-do Hall.
3 wooden statues of Futaishi and two children: Remenant of Kitano Kyoo-do Hall.
Wooden statues of Futaishi and two children, three statues : Remenant of Kitano Kyoo-do Hall.
sen.cmt: 文頭の3をとり、"three statues"の表記を加えました。

sen.j: 応永25年（1418年）、仏師院隆の作。
sen.e: Created in 1418 by Buddhist sculptor Inryu.
Created in 1418 by Buddhist sculptor Inryu.
Created in 1418 by Buddhist sculptor Inryu.

sen.j: だ太鼓縁 一対
sen.e: A pair of Da-drum edges
A pair of Da-drum edges
A pair of Da-drum edges

sen.j: 北野経王堂一切経 5,048帖（うち補写経232帖）－応永19年（1412年）、覚蔵坊増範という僧の発願で書写された一切経で、書写（版本でない）一切経としては日本史上最後のものと言われている。
sen.e: The complete Buddhist scriptures housed within the Kitano Kyoo-do Hall as 5,048 20-sheet bindings (including 232 20-sheet bindings of hand transcribed scriptures): These complete Buddhist scriptures were transcribed (not printed using wood blocks) by the vow of a monk named Gakuzobo Zohan and are said to be the last in Japanese history to have been produced by hand.

The complete Buddhist scriptures housed within the Kitano Kyoo-do Hall as 5,048 20-sheet bindings (including 232 20-sheet bindings of hand transcribed scriptures): These complete Buddhist scriptures were transcribed (not printed using wood blocks) by the vow of a monk named Gakuzobo Zohan and are said to be the last in Japanese history to have been produced by hand.

The complete Buddhist scriptures housed within the Kitano Kyoo-do Hall as 5,048 quires (including 232 quires of hand transcribed scriptures): These complete Buddhist scriptures were transcribed (not printed using wood blocks) by the vow of a monk named Gakuzobo Zohan in 1412 and are said to be the last in Japanese history to have been produced by hand.
sen.cmt: "5,048 20-sheet bindings"→"5048 quires", "232 20-sheet bindings"→"232 quires"としました。

sen.j: おかめ塚とおかめ像
sen.e: Okame-zuka and Okame statue
Okame-zuka and Okame statue
Okame-zuka and Okame statue

sen.j: 像は本堂内にもあり、信者から寄進されたおかめ人形や面も多数展示されている。
sen.e: The statue is housed within the main hall and numerous Okame dolls and masks donated by believers are also displayed.
The statue is housed within the main hall and numerous Okame dolls and masks donated by believers are also displayed.
The statue is housed within the main hall and numerous Okame dolls and masks donated by believers are also displayed.
